string.text: The Mauser Construktion 96 is a semi-automatic pistol originally produced by the producer German Mauser in 7.63x25mm Mauser from 1896 to 1937, to augment the standard 9mm Luger sidearms of the German army. Many military units branded a big red "9" in the grips so soldiers would use the right ammunition.\n It featured an integral box magazine in front of the trigger, a long barrel, a wooden shoulder stock which gives it the stability of a short-barreled rifle and doubles as a holster or carrying case, and a grip shaped like the handle of a broom, earning the gun the nickname "broomhandle" in western countries. In China it was called the "box cannon" due to its rectangular internal magazine.\n This variant is chambered in 9x19mm parabellum.

The Mauser Construktion 96 is a semi-automatic pistol originally produced by the producer German Mauser in 7.63x25mm Mauser from 1896 to 1937, to augment the standard 9mm Luger sidearms of the German army. Many military units branded a big red "9" in the grips so soldiers would use the right ammunition.\n It featured an integral box magazine in front of the trigger, a long barrel, a wooden shoulder stock which gives it the stability of a short-barreled rifle and doubles as a holster or carrying case, and a grip shaped like the handle of a broom, earning the gun the nickname "broomhandle" in western countries. In China it was called the "box cannon" due to its rectangular internal magazine.\n This gun is a conversion to 7.62mm Tokarev, which improves its armor piercing capacity, at the cost of faster degradation due to the old model's tolerance for later high presure rounds.

The Mauser M712 "Schnellfeuer" (rapid fire) is a select fire variant of the Mauser C96 featuring a detachable magazine. Production started in 1932 and ended in 1936, which has led to its unofficial designation of "M1932" by collectors. An extremely successful design, around 98,000 guns were made overall and they had their own series of serial numbers. Small numbers were supplied to the German Wehrmacht during World War II, who designated it the M712.\n This variant is chambered in 9x19mm parabellum and includes the iconic wooden shoulder stock.

The Type 80 is a machine pistol designed in the late 20th Century by the People's Republic of China. Developed by Norinco in the 1970s and influenced by the German M712 Schnellfeuer, it's chambered for the Type 51 cartridge (Chinese copies of the Soviet 7.62x25mm Tokarev cartridge), but it is fed by a 20-round detachable box magazine instead of the 10-round nondetachable magazine in a standard C96. It was designed to replace some of the PLA's Type 54s, especially the Type 54s in service in the Chinese special forces, as a small, light weapon which was required to be good at both attacking and personal defending, similar to that of a PDW.\n For whatever reason, this particular firearm has had its external appearance modified to resemble the M712.
A complex, integrated alteration of the weapon's mechanical and automated parts, which allows its calibre to be changed at the cost of reliability.
